title: How to Season Turkey Burgers

methods.name: Using Dry Seasonings to Add Flavor

steps.headline: Mix cumin with turkey before forming patties for a smoky flavor.
steps.description: Cumin works well with Mexican, North African, Indian, and Middle Eastern flavor profiles. Use 1 teaspoon (2.5 grams) dried cumin for 1 pound (0.45 kg) of ground turkey.

steps.headline: Combine chili powder with turkey before forming patties to add heat.
steps.description: Chili powder pairs best with Latin American flavors. Mix ½ teaspoon (1.5 grams) chili powder with 1.25 pounds (0.57 kg) of ground turkey. Chile powder is a blend of spices including ancho chile powder, paprika, cumin, and Mexican oregano.

steps.headline: Mix thyme into turkey before forming patties for a bright taste.
steps.description: Turkey’s neutral taste means that it can allow other flavors to shine, and thyme pairs well with a Mediterranean flavor profile. Use 1 teaspoon (1.5 grams) of dried thyme for 1.25 pounds (0.57 kg) of ground turkey.

steps.headline: Add salt and pepper to turkey before forming patties.
steps.description: A simple seasoning of salt and pepper works with any flavor profile and is the best choice if you want the burger toppings to be the focus. Use ½ teaspoon (3 grams) and ½ teaspoon of pepper (1 gram) for 1 pound (0.45 kg) of ground turkey. Use seasoning salt or lemon pepper for extra flavor.

methods.name: Adding Other Foods to Improve Flavor and Texture

steps.headline: Mix eggplant with turkey before preparing patties for a meaty flavor.
steps.description: To prepare the eggplant, roast it at 400 °F (204 °C) for 30 minutes. Allow to cool and scrape the flesh from the skin, and then chop finely to make a puree. Use one small eggplant, about 8 ounces (230 g), for each 1 pound (0.45 kg) of turkey.

steps.headline: Mix ricotta cheese with turkey before forming patties.
steps.description: Ricotta cheese will add a mild flavor and moisture without a lot of extra fat. Use ½ cup (124 grams) whole-milk ricotta cheese for 1.25 pounds (0.57 kg) of ground turkey.

steps.headline: Combine ketchup and turkey before forming patties for a classic flavor.
steps.description: This works best if you are planning to add toppings like onions, lettuce, mustard, and more ketchup. Use 2 tablespoons (34 grams) of ketchup for 1 pound (0.45 kg) of ground turkey.

steps.headline: Mix Dijon mustard with turkey before forming patties for a bold flavor.
steps.description: Since Dijon is sharper and spicier than yellow mustard, its flavor will hold up better when cooked..  Use 1 tablespoon (18 grams) mustard for 1 pound (0.45 kg) of ground turkey.

steps.headline: Add onion to turkey before forming patties for a diner-style burger.
steps.description: This is best if you’re planning to serve the burgers with toppings like ketchup, mustard, and pickles. For 1 pound (0.45 kg) of ground turkey, grate half of a medium onion.

steps.headline: Mix shredded cheese with turkey before forming patties.
steps.description: The pockets of cheese in the burger patty give it a juicier interior and a crunchy crust. Use 2 ounces (57 g) of a mild cheese like Monterey Jack per 1 pound (0.45 kg) of ground turkey. For a bolder, cheese-forward burger, try stronger cheeses like sharp cheddar and pepper jack. When choosing a cheese, consider what toppings you will be adding to the burger. For example, cheddar would pair well with classic cheeseburger toppings like lettuce and tomato.

methods.name: Using Different Cooking Techniques to Create Additional Flavor

steps.headline: Sear the burgers to make a flavorful crust.
steps.description: This will also give you a crisp exterior texture. Burgers can be cooked in a skillet on medium-high heat until a crust forms on the bottom, about 3 minutes, and then baked at 375 °F (191 °C) for 5 to 7 minutes. Use a cast iron or oven-safe skillet. Only handle the burgers when flipping in order to keep them from drying out.

steps.headline: Grill the burgers for a smoky taste.
steps.description: Using a charcoal grill will give you the best flavor. Cook over medium-high heat for 3 to 4 minutes per side. Don’t press the burgers down, because you’ll lose the juices and end up with a drier burger.

steps.headline: Cook the burgers over a campfire to add complex flavors.
steps.description: Different types of wood will add different taste notes. For example, apple wood gives meat a light, sweet flavor and hickory adds a hearty taste. To efficiently cook several burgers at once, use a hinged grill basket. They can be purchased online or from a local outdoors supply store.
